danish_publication: En kone i Understed kunde hekse og plejede at skabe sin sön om til en ræv og sende ham over i et andet sogn at stjæle gjæs. Manden i en gård dér havde hørt tale om det, og da han ser en mistænkelig ræv komme luskende, siger han til den: "Nå, er det dig, bitte Jens!" Så blev ræven til en dreng med et rödt forklæde på hovedet, og det var netop heksens dreng. Der kom en mand gående forbi heksens hus, og da stod hun i gangdøren med en strippe og gjorde bevægelse i luften, som om hun malkede. Mælken kom i stråler gjennem luften, så det skummede i strippen. Så snart hun så manden, løb hun ind og slog dören i efter sig. Samme kone havde en lille dreng, der sagde til de andre börn: "Ja, moder kan malke Nörgårds køer på to pinde, men det kan også træffe, hun får ikke andet end skidt."
english_publication: A woman in Understed could do witchcraft and she usually turned her son into a fox and sent him over to another parish to steal geese. A man in a farm over there had heard tell of this and when he sees a suspicious fox come creeping about he says to it, “So, is it you, little Jens?” Then the fox became a boy with a red scarf on his head, and it was the witch’s son. A man walked by the witch’s house and she was standing in the doorway with a piggin (a small wooden pail with one stave extended upward as a handle) and made motions in the air like she was milking. Milk came in streams through the air, so it was foaming all over the piggin. As soon as she saw the man, she ran inside and slammed the door behind her. The same woman had a little boy who said to the other boys: “Well, mom can milk Nørgård’s cows with two pegs, but it can also happen that she gets nothing but shit.”
